abstract.p: Pioneering Hispanic television journalist J J Gonzalez to return to New York market as managing editor of Noticias 41, WXTV evening news program (M)

block.p: J. J. Gonzalez, the first Hispanic journalist in the New York television industry, will return to the market as the managing editor of ''Noticias 41,'' the award-winning evening news program of WXTV, the local affiliate of Univision, the Spanish-language television network, officials said yesterday. He begins Sept. 4.

Mr. Gonzalez began working at WCBS in New York in 1967 and spent nearly three decades as a reporter, assignment editor, national correspondent and public service program director. He accepted a buyout in 1995 and began working as the press secretary for the Bronx borough president, Fernando Ferrer.

J. J. Gonzalez, the first Hispanic journalist in the New York television industry, will return to the market as the managing editor of ''Noticias 41,'' the award-winning evening news program of WXTV, the local affiliate of Univision, the Spanish-language television network, officials said yesterday. He begins Sept. 4.

Mr. Gonzalez began working at WCBS in New York in 1967 and spent nearly three decades as a reporter, assignment editor, national correspondent and public service program director. He accepted a buyout in 1995 and began working as the press secretary for the Bronx borough president, Fernando Ferrer.

Mr. Gonzalez, who grew up in Puerto Rico and the South Bronx, has often lectured about the difficulties of being a Hispanic in television broadcasting. For decades, he has taught in journalism programs for minorities, helping young Hispanics break into the field. He is now an adjunct professor in the multilingual journalism department of Lehman College in the Bronx.
